entry.title: Status Report Configuration and Template Usage in SAP PPM
entry.content:
Hello SAP Experts,

I have some doubts regarding Status Reports in SAP PPM – Project Management and would like clarification on the following points.

 

Question 1: Status Report Creation Options

There are two configuration options available for creating Status Reports:

  1. If the Status Report checkbox is selected under Activate Status Reports, Status Report can be created for the project.
  2. If “Check in Status Reports in SAP DMS” is checked under Activate Status Reports.

Could someone please explain:

  • The purpose of these two options
  • In which scenarios both options need to be selected, or when only the Status Report checkbox is sufficient

 

Question 2: Purpose of Storing Status Reports

What is the purpose of storing Status Reports in:

  • Project Management (PPM)
  • SAP Document Management System (DMS)

In which scenarios should Status Reports be stored only in Project Management, and when is it recommended to store them in SAP DMS?

 

Question 3: Usage of Standard Status Report Objects and Checkbox Restrictions

I see multiple standard DPR objects available, such as:

  • DPR_APPROVAL_HIER
  • DPR_CHECKLIST_HIER
  • DPR_CHECKLIST_ITEM_HIER
  • DPR_NOTES
  • DPR_PHASE_HIER
  • DPR_PROJECT_HIER
  • DPR_STATUS_REPORT_AIF
  • DPR_TASK_HIER

I would like to know how to use all the report templates while creating a status report.

However, according to SAP Help Portal documentation, when using DPR_STATUS_REPORT_STATIC or DPR_STATUS_REPORT_AIF, only the Active and Status Rpt checkboxes must be selected, and the remaining checkboxes under Status Rpt must not be selected.

This creates confusion because:

  • Multiple standard Status Report–related DPR objects exist
  • The system restricts enabling the remaining Status Rpt checkboxes
  • When attempting to select them, the system throws an error stating that the option “cannot be checked”

Could someone please clarify:

  • Why the remaining Status Rpt checkboxes must not be selected when using DPR_STATUS_REPORT_STATIC or DPR_STATUS_REPORT_AIF
  • How the other standard DPR objects (approval, checklist, notes, task, phase, etc.) are used if their corresponding checkboxes are not enabled
    Your inputs and explanations on this topic would be highly appreciated
    Thank you in advance.

entry.title: How to display text within mult-input field?
entry.content:
I've created a multi-input field with value help. But I was not able to display the text instead of key in my multi-input field.
https://sapui5.hana.ondemand.com/sdk/#/topic/04ff5b1a81344a8e8169ea99630ff4e5 

 

I've annotated my field like this:

 

@ui: {
lineItem: [ {
position: 90,
value: '_ZPayrollArea.HCMPayrollArea',
label: 'Payroll Areas',
importance: #HIGH } ],
textArrangement: #TEXT_FIRST
}
_ZPayrollArea;


And the Interface view is linked like this:

--Payroll Area as Detail data
composition [0..*] of Z_I_ZFCompany_PayrllArea_S as _ZPayrollArea

The projection view:

_ZPayrollArea : redirected to composition child Z_C_ZPayrllArea_S,

The projection view detail:

define view entity Z_C_ZPayrllArea_S
--Projection of Interface View Payrolls
as projection on Z_I_ZPayrllArea_S
{
....
--Payroll Area
@Consumption.valueHelpDefinition: [{ entity : { name: 'Z_I_PayrollArea_VH',
element: 'HCMPayrollArea' } }]
key HCMPayrollArea,
--Payroll Area Name
@Semantics.text: true
@search.defaultSearchElement: true
_HCMPayrollArea._Text.HCMPayrollAreaName : localized,
...
/* Associations */
_Root : redirected to parent Z_C_ZRoot_S,
...}

value help:

@Consumption.valueHelpDefault.fetchValues: #AUTOMATICALLY_WHEN_DISPLAYED
define view entity Z_I_PayrollArea_VH
--Select from Payroll Area
as select from I_HCMPayrollArea
{
--Payroll
@search.defaultSearchElement: true
@search.ranking: #HIGH
@search.fuzzinessThreshold: 0.75
@ObjectModel.text.element: [ 'HCMPayrollAreaName' ]
@ui.textArrangement: #TEXT_FIRST
key HCMPayrollArea,
--Payroll Description
@ui.hidden: true
_Text[ 1: Language = $session.system_language ].HCMPayrollAreaName as HCMPayrollAreaName
}

If I try to annotate "@ObjectModel.text.element: [ 'HCMPayrollAreaName' ]" the value help is no longer dispalyed, but the text. And without the annotation, the value help works fine.

How can I display the value help and the text (as textarrangement #TEXT_FIRST)?

entry.title: Re: SAP Public Cloud- data volume / enterprise Project WBS
entry.content:
Good day @Malorie 

Thank you for your question

Regarding your question on volumes of project master data, the Migration Cockpit within the public cloud can surely handle large volumes of project data. For example, over 100,000 WBS elements are technically supported but as you are aware, performance of data migration vary based on various factors (e.g., complexity of your project structures, your system load, staging area capacity, etc.). Therefore, I recommend you:

  • Split your data into packages during upload
  • Consider using staging approach instead of uploading large volume of files.
  • Ensure your project definition is available before dependent WBS elements
  • Ensur you pre-validate your source data to and ensure your data relationships are intact.

 

Here are some references that provide good insights: https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/d5699934e7004d048c4801b552f3b013/12a09cef557b4e09a446ae4d883e46eb.html?locale=en-US

https://help.sap.com/doc/69dd0f1ef0034261ab6e617e0b2beb21/2021.latest/en-US/MigrationObjects_OP_EN.pdf?forSiteMap=true

For your finance closing activities, based on my experience, I would suggest:

  1. For settlement performance:
    • make sure you scale with number of WBS elements and volume of your actuals,
    • when you use public cloud, ensure you avoid running settlements during peak hours.
    • Optimising your CO configurations and number of ranges are essential.
  2. For your Overhead calculation:
    • Note that, if you activate it, that might cause runtime issues if costs are too detailed.
    • Therefore, consider simplifying your costing structures.
  3. For your G/L Integration:
    • One big challenge I am aware of is the correct assignment of the WBS element types to the right G/L accounts. If this is not done correctly, it might block postings or lead to misclassification.

In summary, my general recommendation for your project migration is to make use of Job templates during low-traffic times, make use of the Monitor Application Jobs app to track and troubleshoot and make sure you check your CBC settings for project control parameters (e.g., number of levels allowed).

You may consider using Custom Analytical Queries or CDS Views with filters when you work with large data.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: SAP Signavio: Available Process Diagrams and their Niche Use
entry.content:
SAP Signavio provides several standard process diagram types, each tailored for a different purpose in process modelling, analysis, and optimization. Below is a clear list of the most common diagram types you will encounter in SAP Signavio Process Manager and Journey Modeler, along with what they are used for.

 1. BPMN 2.0 Process Diagram (Business Process Model and Notation)

 

This is the primary and most widely used diagram type in SAP Signavio.

BPMN (Business Process Model and Notation) diagrams are used to visually represent business processes in a standardized, easy-to-understand way. They allow both business users and technical teams to understand how a process works end-to-end.

  • Modelling end-to-end business processes
  • Executable workflows
  • Standardized communication between business and IT

Includes elements like:
Events, tasks, gateways, pools/lanes, data objects, subprocesses, message flows.

1. Documenting Business Processes

BPMN diagrams help organizations clearly document how work is done.

Examples:

  • Order-to-Cash
  • Procure-to-Pay
  • Hire-to-Retire
  • Customer support escalation

2. Process Analysis & Improvement

Teams use BPMN diagrams to identify:

  • Bottlenecks
  • Redundant tasks
  • Delays
  • Opportunities for automation

3. Fit-to-Standard Workshops (SAP Projects)

In SAP implementations (like S/4HANA), BPMN diagrams are used to:

  • Compare current processes vs SAP Best Practices
  • Capture gaps (→ Cloud ALM requirements)
  • Align business teams around a unified process

4. Workflow and Automation Design

BPMN is the standard notation for designing automation flows used in:

  • SAP Build Process Automation
  • SAP Signavio Workflow Accelerator
  • RPA bots
  • Integration flows

The model becomes the blueprint for technical implementation.

5. Training and Communication

Because BPMN is visual and standardized, it is used for:

  • End-user training
  • SOP documentation
  • Cross-team communication

6. System Integration & Monitoring (Cloud ALM)

In SAP Cloud ALM, BPMN diagrams help map:

  • Business process steps → monitoring events
  • Interfaces → message flows
  • Exception handling paths

This allows process-centric monitoring.

2. EPC (Event-Driven Process Chain)

Used mostly by organizations from SAP Solution Manager / ARIS backgrounds.

Used for:

  • High-level process documentation
  • SAP S/4HANA transformation projects
  • Linking events → functions → rules
    1. High-Level Process Documentation (Level 1–2 Processes)

    In Signavio, EPCs are often used to represent high-level, conceptual business processes before going into detailed BPMN modeling.

    Why:

    • Easier for executives and business users
    • Shows process logic without technical detail
    • Good for workshops and business alignment
    1. Documenting AS-IS Processes for SAP Transformations

    Many organizations migrating to S/4HANA use EPCs to document current-state processes, especially if they previously used:

    • SAP Solution Manager
    • ARIS
    • SAP Blueprint methodology

    Why EPC here:

    • Mirrors older SAP documentation formats
    • Simpler representation than BPMN
    • Faster to model at a high level
    1. Building End-to-End Process Landscape / Architecture

    EPCs work very well for process landscape mapping, such as:

    • Level 0 Value Chain
    • Level 1 Core Processes (O2C, P2P, H2R)
    • Level 2 Subprocesses

    In Signavio, many customers model their entire enterprise process hierarchy using EPCs.

    1. Pre-BPMN Modelling for Detailed Design

    Many Signavio users follow a two-step modelling approach:

    Step 1 → EPC:
    Capture conceptual flow (events + functions)

    Step 2 → BPMN:
    Convert detailed flows into executable workflows

    This avoids making BPMN diagrams overly complex.

    5. Fit-to-Standard Workshops (High-Level View)

    During SAP Fit-to-Standard discussions, EPCs can be used to:

    • Introduce the process at a business-friendly level
    • Compare AS-IS to SAP Best Practice TO-BE
    • Identify gaps before creating Cloud ALM requirements
      6. Represent Processes Without Technical Details

    EPC is preferred when:

    • No need to show message flows
    • No need to model system integrations
    • The process is non-automated or conceptual
    • Only business decision flow matters

    This makes EPC the simpler choice compared to BPMN.

    Why Organizations Use EPCs in Signavio Even Today

    Reason

    Explanation

    ✔ Business-friendly visuals

    Functions + events are simple to read

    ✔ Legacy familiarity

    Many SAP customers used EPC for 10+ years

    ✔ Good for high-level processes

    Ideal before jumping into BPMN

    ✔ Works well with process landscapes

    Great for level 0–2 diagrams

    ✔ Not as technical as BPMN

    Suitable for non-IT stakeholders

    EPC vs BPMN in Signavio — When to Use Which

    Use Case

    Recommended

    High-level process overview

    EPC

    Conceptual business flow

    EPC

    SAP AS-IS documentation

    EPC

    End-to-end process landscape

    EPC

    Detailed flow (roles, systems)

    BPMN

    Workflow automation

    BPMN

    Detailed technical integration

    BPMN

     Example EPC Diagram (Signavio Style)

     

     

3. SIPOC Diagram (Supplier – Input – Process – Output – Customer)

 

 

 

Used for:

  • Lean Six Sigma
  • Defining high-level process boundaries
  • Mapping suppliers, inputs, outputs, customers

4. Journey Models (Customer / Employee Journeys)

 

Used for:

  • Mapping customer or employee experiences
  • Identifying pain points and opportunities
  • Aligning processes with customer expectations

6. DMN Decision Model (Decision Model & Notation)

 

Used for:

  • Business rules modelling
  • Decision tables
  • Automation and rule evaluation

Often linked to BPMN processes for decision logic.

7. Organization Charts (Org Chart)

 

Used for:

  • Mapping roles, departments, reporting lines
  • Connecting organizational units to processes

8. Diagram for Process Data / Dictionary Models

(Not a visual diagram like BPMN—more of a structured data model)

Used for:

  • Maintaining global process documentation assets
  • Centralizing terms, IT systems, roles, KPIs

Summary Table

Diagram Type

Purpose

BPMN 2.0

Detailed end-to-end process modeling

EPC

High-level SAP process documentation

SIPOC

Quick scoping and boundary definition

Value Chain / Hierarchy

Process architecture and taxonomy

Journey Models

Customer/employee experience mapping

DMN Decision Models

Business rules & logic

Org Charts

Organizational structure mapping

Dictionary Models

Central documentation repository

How BPMNs Connect with SAP CloudALM implementation and Operations (Chapter 2)

Using Signavio in S4/Hana Conversion along with SAP Activate methodology(Chapter 3)

entry.title: How to Fetch Custom Fields in FI Customer Invoice Adobe Form S/4HANA Public Cloud
entry.content:
Hello Experts,

I am currently working on an SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Implementation and Involved in Custom Adobe Form Development using Adobe Lifecycle Designer for the FI Customer Invoice (Credit Note & Debit Note).              The Form is Triggered via Manage Journal Entries : Create Correspondence.

We have successfully mapped all Standard Fields using the standard Data Source. However, we now have a requirement to map additional Custom Fields in the Form.

Currently, standard fields are mapped using the standard Data Source. however, there is a requirement to fetch and Display additional Custom Fields in the Adobe Form. To achieve this, we explored enhancement options using Custom Logic BADIs and identified the Business Context FIN_ACDOC_ITEM_SUBSTITUTION. However, this BADI is triggered before Document posting, at which point the Accounting Document Number is not yet available. As a result, it is not possible to perform a SELECT query on the custom CDS view or related tables to retrieve the required custom field values. Furthermore, no suitable BADI or Business Context triggered after posting has been identified to support form enhancement for this scenario.

The current requirement is to identify a supported enhancement solution in S/4HANA Public Cloud to enhance the FI Customer Invoice Adobe Form by fetching and mapping custom fields, preferably using a post posting BADI or any other supported enhancement option.

Additional Information Provided :-

Application Name :- Manage Journal Entries                                                                                                                        Form :- SAP 21 FI Customer Invoice                                                                                                                                        Application Object ID :- Accounting Document (FI_ACCDOC)                                                                                          Output Type :- Invoice (INVOICE)                                                                                                                                                  Channel :- Print                                                                                                                                                                        Business Context for Custom Field :- Accounting : Journal Entry Item                                                                                  Data Source :- FDP_FFO_FI_INVOICE_SRV                                                                                                                                  Standard Form Template :- FIN_FO_CORR_FICUS_INV_E

Is there any supported BADI or Business Context in S/4HANA Public Cloud to enhance a custom Adobe Form after posting or else Alternatively, is there a supported way to fetch custom fields using CDS extensions, form enhancements, or output parameter mapping ?

 

Thank you,
Yash Rudraksha,

entry.title: SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud – Dunning Notice Email to Customer + Multiple Contact Persons from BP
entry.content:
Hi SAP Community,

We are using SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud (3SL) and are trying to configure Dunning Notice emails so that email IDs are picked dynamically from BP master data, without hardcoding email addresses.

Requirement

When a dunning run is executed:

Email should be sent to the Customer BP email

Email should also be sent to all linked Contact Persons’ email IDs

Multiple Contact Persons should receive the email automatically

All email IDs must be derived only from BP master (Customer + Contact Person)

What we have already configured

  1. BP Master

Customer BP has email maintained in Address → Communication

Contact Person BPs have email maintained

Relationships maintained: Has Contact Person, Has Dunning Recipient

  1. Output Parameter Determination – Receiver

Application: Dunning

Determination Step: Receiver

Decision Table: DT_RECEIVER

Entry maintained:

Output Type = DUNN_NOTICE

Account Type = D (Customer) Role = D Exclusive Indicator = false

Note: We do not see CP (Contact Person) as a selectable Role in Receiver.

  1. Output Parameter Determination – Email Recipient

Determination Step: Email Recipient

Decision Table: DT_EMAIL_RECEIVER

Entries maintained:

Row 1: Output Type = DUNN_NOTICE,  Email Type = TO, Email Address = Context → Customer → Email Address

Row 2: Output Type = DUNN_NOTICE, Email Type = TO Email Address = Context → Contact Person → Email Address

 

Issue / Clarification Required

CP (Contact Person) does not appear as a Role in Receiver determination

It is unclear whether Contact Persons are implicitly derived during Email Recipient determination

Despite maintaining BP relationships and Email Recipient context mapping, the behavior is not clearly documented

Questions

  1. In SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, is it standard behavior that Contact Persons are not selectable in the Receiver Role?
  2. Is the above configuration sufficient for sending dunning emails to:
    1. Customer BP email, and
    2. All Contact Person emails marked as Dunning Recipient?
  3. Is there any additional configuration or prerequisite required for Contact Person email determination?
  4. Is there any SAP documentation or note confirming this behavior?

entry.title: Re: MDI to Planon Integration delta token not matching
entry.content:
Hi Jastin,

As the delta tokens are linked to a specific MDI service instance the delta tokens need to be updated in order to have a working connection again.

To sync the objects manually from Planon side the "Sync" action on the objects need to be used., so the delta tokens can be updated.

entry.title: Re: Fiori APP, F2689, Record Results for Inspection Lots
entry.content:
Just for the record - you are talking about Inspection Points, not Inspection Lot as indicated in your request, correct? App F2689 is about inspection points.

I bet you are a victim of the restriction which only applies to the app but not for the GUI - the Inspection Point Field combination you use in the routing header must not contain anything else than date and time. We had defined our own, which has a 3rd field in the combination and asks in the GUI for the field to complete before the inspection starts, but in the app you just don't see that inspection lot.

Can you share which is your Inspection Point Field in the Routing header? If you use 101 (date/time) it should work, might be worth a try.

Note: this only applies to S/4HANA On Premise / Private Cloud. In the Public Cloud, the SAP help shows that this restriction does not apply anymore, there is more possible.

entry.title: CAP Multitenancy: Connectivity Service returns 401 invalid_client despite correct provisioning setup
entry.content:
I’m working on a CAP multitenant app in Cloud Foundry and I keep getting a 401 error when trying to use the Connectivity service, even though I’ve added it as a dependency both in my mta.yaml and in the provisioning dependencies handler. 
What makes this confusing is: I can successfully read subscriber destinations, but Connectivity fails even though it is also bound.

In my app:

  • Connectivity is listed as a dependency in mta.yaml
  • I return both the destination and connectivity xsappname in the dependencies handler
  • The xsappname values look correct in my environment variables
  • I’ve redeployed and double-checked the service bindings

But I still get this error:

Error: Could not fetch client credentials token for service of type connectivity: HTTP response ... was 401: {"error":"invalid_client","error_description":"Bad credentials"}

Main package versions:
@SAP-cloud-sdk/connectivity: ^4.2.0
@SAP-cloud-sdk/http-client: ^4.2.0
@SAP/cds: ^9.5.2
@SAP/cds-mtxs: ^3.5.1
@SAP/xssec: ^4

I have already reviewed the following SAP Community post and the related blog comments, but unfortunately the suggested approach did not resolve the issue in my case:

https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-q-a/cap-multitenancy-connectivity/qaq-p/12493182

Has anyone else run into this? Is there something I might be missing?

entry.title: Troubleshooting SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) Access Errors for BW Live Data in Microsoft Edge
entry.content:
Introduction

SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) provides powerful real-time analytics through BW Live connections. However, users frequently face access issues when opening BW Live stories in Microsoft Edge.

In most cases, these problems are not caused by BW or SAC models, but by:

  • Browser security restrictions in Microsoft Edge
  • Missing SAC or BW roles
  • Incomplete user profile or license assignment

This guide focuses only on BW Live access issues in Microsoft Edge and how to resolve them.

 

  1. Common SAC Access Errors for BW Live Users
  2. Missing User Profile or Role (BW Live Context)

Typical message:
“Please contact your administrator to assign the required role.”

What it means:

  • Your SAC user profile is not created, or
  • Your SAC license is missing, or
  • Required BW Live–related roles are not assigned

Without these, BW Live stories will not open, even if import models work.

Action:

  • Confirm SAC license assignment
  • Confirm BW Live access role with your administrator

 

  1. Browser Authorization Prompt in Microsoft Edge

What you see:

  • Microsoft Edge asks for username and password when opening a BW Live story

What it means:

  • User profile creation has started
  • SAC license is not yet fully assigned

This issue is more visible in BW Live stories, because they require live authentication.

Action:

  • Wait for license completion
  • Check request status with the administrator

 

  1. Unauthorized Error Due to IDM Lock (BW Live)

Typical error:

  • “Unauthorized”
  • SAML2 authentication error

What it means:

  • Your SAP user ID is locked in Identity Management (IDM)
  • BW Live authentication fails immediately

Action:

  • Contact administrator
  • Request IDM unlock

 

  1. BW Live Connection Fails in Microsoft Edge

Typical symptoms:

  • BW Live story opens but data does not load
  • “Unable to connect to BW system”
  • Blank tables or charts

Most common root cause in Edge:

  • Third-party cookies are blocked

This issue affects BW Live only, not import models.

 

  1. Microsoft Edge Settings Required for BW Live

Third-Party Cookies (Critical for BW Live)

Microsoft Edge may automatically disable third-party cookies every 90 days.

When this happens:

  • BW Live authentication fails
  • SAC stories stop working suddenly

 

How to Enable Third-Party Cookies in Edge

  1. Open a BW Live SAC story in Microsoft Edge
  2. Look for the eye symbol in the browser address bar
  3. Click the eye symbol
  4. Enable third-party cookies for the SAC site
  5. Refresh the page

In most cases, BW Live data loads immediately.

 

  1. Pop-Ups and Redirects (BW Live Requirement)

BW Live uses pop-ups for:

  • Authentication
  • Variable prompts

If pop-ups are blocked, BW Live cannot complete login.

Edge Configuration

  1. Go to Edge Settings
  2. Open Cookies and Site Permissions
  3. Select Pop-ups and redirects
  4. Add your SAC tenant URL to Allow

Reload the BW Live story after this change.

  1. Role-Based Access for BW Live Data

If SAC opens but BW Live data fails:

Possible reason:

  • Missing BW Live–specific role or view authorization

Action:

  • Ask administrator to raise a GRC request
  • Ensure both:
    • SAC role
    • BW Live / BW authorization role
      are included

 

Checking GRC Request Status

  1. Open GRC Home
  2. Navigate to Search Requests
  3. Track approval and completion

Do not rely only on email updates.

 

  1. Confirmation That BW Live Access Is Ready

You will receive an email from the SAP Authorization Batch system when:

  • SAC license is assigned
  • User profile is created
  • BW Live roles are active

After this, BW Live stories should open correctly in Microsoft Edge.

 

Final Tips for BW Live Users on Microsoft Edge

  • This guide applies only to BW Live data
  • Import models are usually not affected
  • Microsoft Edge needs periodic cookie checks
  • Pop-ups must be allowed
  • Both SAC and BW roles are mandatory

Checking browser settings first can save hours of troubleshooting.

 

Conclusion

Most SAC access errors for BW Live users in Microsoft Edge are caused by browser security settings or missing roles, not by BW or SAC issues. With the right Edge configuration and proper role assignment, BW Live stories work reliably and smoothly.

entry.title: SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud – Dunning Notice Email to Customer + Multiple Contact Persons from BP Maste
entry.content:
Hi SAP Community,

We are using SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud (3SL) and are trying to configure Dunning Notice emails so that email IDs are picked dynamically from BP master data, without hardcoding email addresses.

Requirement

When a dunning run is executed:

Email should be sent to the Customer BP email

Email should also be sent to all linked Contact Persons’ email IDs

Multiple Contact Persons should receive the email automatically

All email IDs must be derived only from BP master (Customer + Contact Person)

What we have already configured

  1. BP Master

Customer BP has email maintained in Address → Communication

Contact Person BPs have email maintained

Relationships maintained: Has Contact Person, Has Dunning Recipient

  1. Output Parameter Determination – Receiver

Application: Dunning

Determination Step: Receiver

Decision Table: DT_RECEIVER

Entry maintained:

Output Type = DUNN_NOTICE

Account Type = D (Customer) Role = D Exclusive Indicator = false

Note: We do not see CP (Contact Person) as a selectable Role in Receiver.

  1. Output Parameter Determination – Email Recipient

Determination Step: Email Recipient

Decision Table: DT_EMAIL_RECEIVER

Entries maintained:

Row 1: Output Type = DUNN_NOTICE,  Email Type = TO, Email Address = Context → Customer → Email Address

Row 2: Output Type = DUNN_NOTICE, Email Type = TO Email Address = Context → Contact Person → Email Address

 

Issue / Clarification Required

CP (Contact Person) does not appear as a Role in Receiver determination

It is unclear whether Contact Persons are implicitly derived during Email Recipient determination

Despite maintaining BP relationships and Email Recipient context mapping, the behavior is not clearly documented

Questions

  1. In SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, is it standard behavior that Contact Persons are not selectable in the Receiver Role?
  2. Is the above configuration sufficient for sending dunning emails to:
    1. Customer BP email, and
    2. All Contact Person emails marked as Dunning Recipient?
  3. Is there any additional configuration or prerequisite required for Contact Person email determination?
  4. Is there any SAP documentation or note confirming this behavior?

entry.title: SAP Analytics Cloud Scripting – My Practical Learnings (Part 1 of 2)
entry.content:
Introduction

While working with BW Live stories in SAP Analytics Cloud Advanced Mode, I learned that scripting must be defensive, explicit, and user-driven.
In this blog, I share the first three scripting learnings that consistently worked in real projects.

All examples below are error-free and production-safe.

 

  1. Always Convert Text Input Values Explicitly

Learning

Text Input widgets always return strings.
Using them directly in calculations or BW variables leads to errors.

Explicit conversion is mandatory.

 

Working Script Example

// Read value from Text Input

var inputValue = InputField_1.getValue();

 

// Convert string to number safely

var numericValue = ConvertUtils.stringToNumber(inputValue);

Why this works

  • No implicit type conversion
  • No runtime errors
  • Fully supported in SAC

 

  1. Keep User Input Simple, Convert Units in Script

Learning

Business users prefer entering simple numbers, such as millions.
BW Live variables expect full numeric values.

The script must handle the conversion.

 

Working Script Example

// Convert million value to full amount and feed BW variable

Table_Main.getDataSource()

    .setVariableValue("VAR_COST_MIN", numericValue * 1000000);

Benefits

  • Clean user experience
  • Accurate BW filtering
  • No confusion for business users

 

  1. Refresh BW Live Data Only After Setting Variables

Learning

BW Live does not automatically refresh after variable updates.
Refreshing too early or multiple times causes inconsistent behavior.

Always refresh once, after all variables are set.

 

Working Script Example

// Refresh BW Live data after variable assignment

Table_Main.getDataSource().refreshData();

Best Practice

  • One refresh per Execute button
  • Never refresh inside loops

 

Conclusion – Part 1

These three learnings form the foundation of stable BW Live scripting:

  • Explicit conversion
  • User-friendly units
  • Controlled refresh

In Part 2, I will cover advanced but safe patterns for helper tables and dynamic filtering.

entry.title: SAP Analytics Cloud Scripting – My Practical Learnings (Part 2 of 2)
entry.content:
Introduction

After mastering input handling and refresh control, the next challenge in BW Live is dynamic filtering based on measure values.

Direct measure filtering is limited, so I learned to use helper tables with result set logic. The patterns below are stable and production-safe.

 

  1. Use Helper Tables to Filter Based on Measure Values

Learning

SAC does not allow direct measure-based filters easily.
A helper table can read result sets and drive intelligent filtering.

 

Working Script Example

// Get helper table data source

var dsSource = Table_Helper.getDataSource();

 

// Read result set

var rs = dsSource.getResultSet();

This works reliably after data is loaded.

 

  1. Always Handle Zero and Blank Measure Values Safely

Learning

Zero or blank values distort charts and trends.
They must be filtered carefully without breaking the story.

 

Working Script Example

// Create array for valid dimension members

var dimList = ArrayUtils.create(Type.string);

 

for (var i = 0; i < rs.length; i++) {

 

    var dimObj = rs[i]["DIM_KEY"];

    var measObj = rs[i]["@MeasureDimension"];

 

    if (measObj !== null &&

        measObj.formattedValue !== "0" &&

        measObj.formattedValue !== "") {

 

        dimList.push(dimObj.id);

    }

}

Why this is safe

  • No undefined access
  • Handles blank and zero values
  • Works for BW Live

 

  1. Always Handle the “No Valid Data” Scenario

Learning

If no valid records exist, filters must be removed.
Otherwise, users see empty or broken visuals.

 

Working Script Example

var dsTarget = Table_Main.getDataSource();

 

if (dimList.length > 0) {

    dsTarget.setDimensionFilter("DIM_KEY", dimList);

} else {

    dsTarget.removeDimensionFilter("DIM_KEY");

}

This guarantees:

  • No stuck filters
  • Predictable behavior

 

Conclusion – Part 2

My key takeaway from SAC scripting is simple:

Stable scripts matter more than clever scripts.

By using helper tables, explicit checks, and safe filtering logic, BW Live stories remain fast, reliable, and easy to maintain.

entry.title: Announcement Regarding Unsupported Business Rule in Sap SuccessFactors
entry.content:
Introduction

This Blog is to notify the SAP Community of an Unsupported Business Rule "Has Incomplete Forms"  which will be removed in the Upcoming Product Feature Release Cycle.

Unsupported Business Rule:

During a recent exploration of potential workarounds for a client requirement to send automated Reminders for Overdue Performance Forms, I came across the business rule “Has Incomplete Forms in Inbox” which I felt would solve the purpose of Identifying the Overdue Forms in the Inbox of the Employee/Managers/HR. However, during testing, the rule did not function as expected which was confirmed by the Rule Trace. Additionally, I was unable to locate any official documentation for this rule in the SAP Help Portal and Official Documentations from SAP.

I escalated the issue to the SAP Product Team by raising a Ticket, who reviewed it with the Product Engineering team and confirmed that this business rule is no longer supported and will be removed in the upcoming Product Feature Release.

If you are currently using this rule or have configurations dependent on it, please be aware that it may not work correctly and will not be available going forward. It is recommended to review your setup and plan any necessary adjustments ahead of the release. This is a very rare business rule, and I highly doubt if anyone is using it currently, However Community needs to be informed for changes / deprecations in advance, so the configurations are reviewed, and any necessary change management is planned well ahead rather than last minute rush.

Attaching the Confirmation from the SAP Product Team

Conclusion


I hope this update helps you avoid potential issues in your configurations and ensures a smooth transition ahead of the upcoming release. If anyone has questions, feel free to ask—this could benefit the wider community as we adapt to this change. In case you are wondering how this has been achieved without the above-mentioned Business Rule, please do check out my Other Blog attached below

Recurring Automated Reminders for Over Due Steps -... - SAP Community

entry.title: Re: Sort a Chart by Variance via Script in SAC
entry.content:
Sorting by Variance created directly in the chart is not supported via scripting in SAP Analytics Cloud.
The sortByValue() method works only with real measures and not with visual comparisons like Actual versus Plan.
Chart quick menu sorting works because it is handled at the user interface level and not by the scripting API.
As a workaround, create Variance as a calculated measure in the BW query or SAC model.
Once it exists as a real measure, it can be sorted using sortByValue().

entry.title: Re: Add a Ameasure to a numeric point chart using script...
entry.content:
In SAP Analytics Cloud, a numeric point accepts only measures, not dimension members like Account.
addMember() is meant for dimensions, so it adds Account as a category, not as a measure.
To add a measure, you must use the measures dimension with addMeasure() on the Value Axis.
Example (working approach):

Chart_1.getDataSource().addMeasure("Revenue");

You cannot add an Account node directly as a numeric point unless it is exposed as a measure in the model or BW query.

entry.title: Re: How to set SAC chart tooltip values using script
entry.content:
This is a known limitation in SAP Analytics Cloud when using Input Dimension Control.
When the dimension is changed dynamically, the tooltip shows only the member value and not the dimension name.
Tooltips are handled at the visual layer and cannot be modified or refreshed through scripting.
There is no API available to force the tooltip to display the current dimension name.
A practical workaround is to show the selected dimension name in a Text widget and update it using script.

entry.title: Re: SAC date filters
entry.content:
This cannot be achieved fully using a single Story-level date filter due to model and calculation limitations in SAP Analytics Cloud.
Story filters always pass a date range, but measures using RESTRICT or rolling logic expect a single month and will fail when multiple periods are passed.
There is no supported way to dynamically convert a Story date range into a single month for selected measures.
The practical workaround is to keep a Story filter for range-based metrics and control single-month metrics using page-level filters or scripting.
For usability, show the refresh date and applied logic clearly using Text widgets, which is the SAP-recommended design approach.

entry.title: Re: How to maintain documentation for data elements on Cl...
entry.content:
Hello Daniel,

Data element long texts are displayed by default in UI5 (Fiori) apps in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition, regardless of type (standard or custom).

To create data element long texts, run transaction SE11 in the relevant ABAP backend, search for a data element, edit it, click Documentation, enter your text, save and release your changes:

The texts will then be displayed in the SAP Companion Help Panel and on the app UI when you click the question mark next to a field. This is also supported in WalkMe.

Francesco

entry.title: Re: Is there a practice system for learning SAP Business Data Cloud?
entry.content:
Hi @Yogananda  @MarkyMark Why does free trial has so many restriction?

The SAP BDC free trial has significant limitations that make hands-on learning extremely difficult. For example:

  • You cannot create data products that can be shared with Databricks

  • Space creation authorization is restricted

  • BW PCE is not available

  • Cant install new app

These restrictions prevent users from practicing many of the new and important features of the platform.

This raises a key concern:
How are individuals supposed to learn and build real skills if they do not have access to a system through their employer?

If full capabilities cannot be offered for free, there should at least be a simple, self-service paid option for individuals. Currently, even paid access often requires:

  • Being an SAP Partner, or

  • Having an employer purchase the system first

As a result, individuals who want to invest in learning on their own are effectively blocked.

With so many restrictions, the trial system defeats its own purpose. A trial should enable users to explore and practice most of the platform’s key and newly released features , not limit them to a subset that provides only theoretical exposure.

entry.title: Do you know how much you are printing?
entry.content:
As you are surely aware, the on-prem print solution SAP Interactive Forms by Adobe (IFbA) runs on a SAP NetWeaver Application Server Java and it is precisely this Java server that will go out of Mainstream Maintenance at the end of 2027 and out of Extended Maintenance at the end of 2030.

The maintenance strategy for SAP NetWeaver is documented here: https://pages.community.sap.com/topics/abap/netweaver-maintenance-strategy 

 

Successor On-Premise Solution

SAP HANA Extended Application Services, Advanced Model (XSA) will be the successor platform for Adobe Document Services (ADS).

SAP plans to deliver this option Q1, 2027. Customers can decide to switch from the ADS on NetWeaver AS Java to SAP Forms service by Adobe or the ADS on XSA. This guarantees long-term support of Adobe-based forms functionality for S/4 HANA on-premise solutions.

If you decide to switch from your existing on-premise SAP NetWeaver solution to the cloud service SAP Forms service by Adobe it might be interesting to know how much you are currently printing. Because the pricing model in the cloud differs from on-premise.

Pricing Model

The main concept is billable requests. So when you send a technical request to the ADS to generate a form it also involves a billable request. But a billable request is not quite the same as a technical request. So if I send one technical request to generate a pdf comprising 25 pages that is 5 billable requests, because 5 pages is one billable request. If you set a digital signature, it’s a billable request. If you do a print preview it’s a billable request and we don’t distinguish between interactive and print form cause they both generate a load on the ADS and we don’t distinguish between system type so whether you’re dealing with a quality system or a productive system or a development system it still generates a load on the ADS and so it costs money. The licensing options can be found in the SAP Discovery Center. The cheapest one is known as the BTPEA. BTP Enterprise Agreement. There is another option which is more flexible but generally more expensive known as Pay-as-you-Go.

Price Estimation

Customers can log render calls via settings in NW AS JAVA.

Collect Data: For the analysis, Python* can be used or the following dedicated ABAP report:

2714231 - IFbA: Configuration for collecting ADS performance data - SAP for Me .

Please pay special attention to section IV in the note.

Analyze Collected Data: 

3690131 - Improve Stability for FP_ADS_PERF_LOG_ANALYZER - SAP for Me

*Python can be executed directly at the operating system level (Linux / Windows) and can read the native file system.

Picture 1: Analyze collected data, display in Table, calculate directly or export to Excel

Picture 2: Calculate Form Request

NOTE: Form requests shown are estimates only based on the usage logs and do not constitute a quote or an offer by SAP.
Whilst every care is taken to ensure the information is correct, no responsibility is accepted by SAP for its accuracy.
Contact SAP if you need assistance or additional information on pricing. 

Q&A regarding the reports:

Q: How long should the log ideally run, is 1 week sufficient?

A: If you want to know how much is generated in a week, the logs should run for a week.

Q: How large will the log file be; do we need to implement special measures for storing the log?

A: There are no explicit recommendations for the tool; around 10MB per file should be fine. Log rotation should be used for storage, as this creates new log files when the 10MB limit has been reached.

Q: What would be the best method to transport all the log files to the "analysis system"?

A: Dependent on the analysis tool. ABAP requires the upload of files / ZIP via SAPGUI

For very large amounts of data (> 1GB), Python should be faster/more efficient.

NOTE: This method is a workaround. No guarantee as to the accuracy or completeness of the resulting outcomes.

Did you know that there’s a comprehensive range of e-learnings available for SAP Engineering Control Center | SAP ECTR? Delivered by DSC Software AG, a long-standing SAP partner, these learning modules are designed to make your professional growth easy, flexible, and engaging.

These e-learnings offer up-to-date content presented in an easy-to-understand format, enabling you to integrate learning seamlessly into your daily work.

  • Modern way of learning: Learn with flexibility, whenever and wherever you want, according to your individual schedule.
  • Repetition made easy: Repeat the content anytime to consolidate your knowledge, even after the course completion.

  • Available on all common devices: Access the e-learning without any restrictions from your smartphone, tablet, or computer.
  • A perfect basis for further trainings: Build on a solid basic knowledge that prepares you for further trainings. 
  • Learning journeys provide guidance and show progress: Follow structured paths that help you stay on track and visualize your learning achievements.

The content is specifically tailored for distinct target groups, such as users and administrators.

entry.title: Integrating Skills with Talent Intelligence Hub
entry.content:
Certify Your Skills Integration with SAP SuccessFactors

The Problem: Fragmented Skill Data and Its Consequences

Organizations today face a critical challenge: integrating skills data across multiple systems to support dynamic talent strategies. Without standardized integration between third-party solutions and SAP SuccessFactors Talent Intelligence Hub (TIH) and Job Profile Builder (JPB), partners risk inconsistent skill assignments, inefficient job architecture setup, and fragmented employee experiences. This lack of alignment hinders innovation, reduces operational efficiency, and compromises the ability to deliver trusted, scalable solutions for customers.

Why This Certification Matters

With the business landscape transforming at an unprecedented pace, skills now serve as the new currency for organizations focused on attracting, growing, and retaining their best talent. To help partners deliver seamless skill integration and create trusted experiences for customers, SAP SuccessFactors now offers a partner certification program for solutions connecting to Talent Intelligence Hub (TIH) and Job Profile Builder (JPB).

What This Certification Delivers

This certification serves as a blueprint for Reliable Skills Integration with the key assurances listed below

  • Standardized integration scope for third-party solutions.
  • Optimized performance through defined technical guardrails.
  • Accurate and relevant skill assignment for employees.

Partners who meet all criteria can earn an official “SAP Certified” solution logo and get the solution details listed in SAP Certified Solutions Directory.

For partner who plan to commercialize their solution on the SAP Store, certification ensures they are recognized as SAP Certified, signaling the quality and reliability of their integration to customers.

Integration Scenarios in Scope – Where and How Your Solution Connects

Job Profile Builder

  • Import and export of JPB entities via REST APIs and Integration Center.

Talent Intelligence Hub

  • Import and export of skills in the Attributes Library using flat files via SAP SuccessFactors Integration Center.
  • Valid use cases for updating an employee’s Growth Portfolio via inbound API.

Integration Patterns

  • API-based integrations (recommended whenever available).
  • File-based integrations for scenarios where APIs are not supported.

Prerequisites for Certification

To qualify, partners must:

  • Set up Talent Intelligence Hub in their SAP SuccessFactors instance following the guide Using Talent Intelligence Hub- SAP Help Portal.
  • Integrate via REST API services or use standard integration templates available on SAP Business Accelerator Hub:
    • Attribute Library Import/Export Templates.
      • Overview | SuccessFactors Talent Intelligence Hub Library Import Templates | SAP Business Accelerator Hub
      • Overview | SuccessFactors Talent Intelligence Hub Library Export Templates | SAP Business Accelerator Hub
    • Growth Portfolio Import/Export Templates.
      • Overview | SuccessFactors Talent Intelligence Hub Growth Portfolio Import Template | SAP Business Accelerator Hub
      • Overview | SuccessFactors Talent Intelligence Hub Growth Portfolio Export Template | SAP Business Accelerator Hub
  • Implement OAuth 2.0 authentication for API connectivity.
  • Provide:
    • Scalability test results.
    • Operations guide.
    • Support procedures for their interface.
  • Implement the Application Interface Register Key (AIR Key) when connecting via OData APIs, REST APIs, or web services.

Certification Journey

Achieving SAP SuccessFactors Skills Integration Certification is a structured process designed to ensure quality, reliability, and compliance with SAP standards. The journey consists of six key steps, as illustrated in the Certification Process Overview

 Resources for Detailed Guidance:

SAP Partner Portal | Software certification

Certification and Technical Services | SAP Partners

Benefits for Partners

  • Credibility: Showcase your solution with the “SAP Certified” logo.
  • Market Access: Publish on SAP Store and reach global customers.
  • Innovation Support: Access SAP SuccessFactors product management guidance through SAP PartnerEdge – Build.

How to Get Started

We are currently running a beta pilot with selected partners. The certification program will open to the broader partner community in January 2026.

For enrollment and details, contact the SAP ICC team at:
📧icc@sap.com

Call to Action

Ready to certify your integration and unlock new opportunities?
Start preparing today and position your solution for success in the SAP ecosystem.

entry.title: Origin Acceptance Process in SAP S/4HANA – Step-by-Step Guide with 107 & 109 Movements
entry.content:
✍️ Introduction

Origin Acceptance allows materials to be inspected and accepted at the supplier’s location, ensuring that only compliant goods are released for use. From a system perspective, SAP manages this through special goods movements (such as 107 and 109) that clearly distinguish between financial ownership and physical receipt, providing transparency across logistics and finance.

💼 Business Example

Consider a manufacturing company sourcing precision-engineered components from an overseas vendor. These components are expensive, quality-sensitive, and must comply with strict technical specifications.

Instead of waiting for the goods to arrive at the plant and then performing quality checks, the company:

  • Enables Origin Acceptance at the material master level
  • Performs inspection at the vendor premises
  • Posts a 107 movement to record valuated stock while the goods are still in transit
  • Releases the stock for use only after physical receipt via 109 movement

This approach helps the business:

  • Avoid rejections and return logistics after delivery
  • Ensure early financial visibility of procured inventory
  • Maintain tighter quality control and compliance
  • Improve warehouse planning and production readiness

In the rest of this blog, we’ll explore the step-by-step configuration and execution of the Origin Acceptance process in SAP S/4HANA, from material master setup to stock and accounting impact, using standard SAP transactions and best practices from Sourcing & Procurement.

Step 1: Define Structure of Data Screens for Each Screen Sequence (Transaction: OMT3)

To use Origin Acceptance, the indicator must be visible and editable in the Material Master – Purchasing View.

SPRO Path: SPRO → Logistics – General → Material Master → Configuring the Material Master → Define Structure of Data Screens for Each Screen Sequence (OMT3)

🔎 Why this step is important:
Without this configuration, the origin acceptance indicator cannot be maintained at the material level, making the process unavailable during procurement.

Here, the purchasing screen sequence is adjusted so that the Origin Acceptance field appears in the relevant sub-screen.

Step 2: Create Material Master Record - Activate Origin Acceptance

In the Purchasing View of the material master, enable the Origin Acceptance indicator.

This setting ensures that whenever the material is procured, SAP enforces origin-based inspection and restricts standard goods receipt postings.

📌 Key Control:
Once activated, the system will block standard 101 Goods Receipt, forcing the use of special movements (107/109).

Step 3: Create Purchase Requisition (Transaction: ME51N / Manage Purchase Requistion)

Create a purchase requisition for the material with origin acceptance enabled.

The PR behaves like a standard procurement document, but the origin acceptance requirement flows automatically into subsequent documents.

🧠 Business Perspective:
At this stage, procurement planning remains unchanged, ensuring no disruption to purchasing operations.

Step 4: Create Purchase Order (Transaction: ME21N / Manage Purchase Order)

Create the Purchase Order with reference to the PR.

In the Item Details → Delivery tab, verify that the Origin Acceptance indicator is active.

✔️ This confirms that the PO is subject to inspection at the supplier’s premises.

Step 5: Check Stock Status before positing GRN (Transaction: MMBE)

Before posting any goods movement, check stock using MMBE.

You’ll typically observe:

  • Unrestricted Stock: Existing quantity

  • On-Order Stock: Quantity from the open PO

📊 This gives clarity on current availability versus expected receipts.

Step 6: Attempt Goods Receipt - System Restriction (Transaction: MIGO / Post Goods Movement)

When attempting to post a 101 Goods Receipt, SAP will block the transaction.

🚫 System Behavior:
Because origin acceptance is active, SAP does not allow direct posting to unrestricted stock.

✔️ This enforces inspection at the source before goods are made available for use

when you perform check

Step 7: Post Goods Receipt with Movement Type 107 (MIGO)

Change the movement type to 107 – GR to Valuated Stock in Transit and post the document.

What happens at this stage:

  • Stock is recorded as Receiving Valuated Stock in Transit
  • Accounting entries are generated
  • Ownership is transferred, but goods are not yet physically received

💰 Financial Impact:
Stock and GR/IR accounts are updated, providing early financial visibility.

Step 8: Check Stock after 107 Posting (MIGO)

After posting movement 107:

  • Quantity appears under Receiving Valuated Stock in Transit
  • No increase in unrestricted stock

📦 This reflects goods accepted at origin but still in transit.

Step 9: Post Movement Type 109 - Release Stock for Usage (MIGO)

Once the goods physically arrive at the warehouse/location, post movement type 109 with reference to the same PO.

System Impact:

  • Stock moves from Valuated Stock in Transit to Unrestricted Use
  • ❌ No accounting document is generated (already posted during 107)

🧾 This step purely represents logistical receipt, not financial posting.

Step 10: Final Stock verification (Transaction: MMBE)

After movement 109:

  • Stock is available in Unrestricted Use
  • Materials can now be consumed in production or sold

✅ The Origin Acceptance cycle is now complete.

🔑 Key Takeaways from the Process

  • Origin Acceptance separates financial ownership from physical receipt
  • Quality checks are completed before goods reach the warehouse
  • Movements 107 and 109 ensure transparency across MM and FI
  • Ideal for high-value, regulated, or quality-sensitive materials

 

If you found this guide helpful, don’t miss my other SAP MM WM blogs covering real-world automation, configuration tips, and best practices for procurement, inventory management, and warehouse management.

Click to view other SAP MM WM Blogs - SAP Community

 

Regards,

Leelamohan
